moves.1. e4: I start out with e4. Very common
moves.2... Nc6: Nc6, another regular move in the King's pawn opening.
moves.3. d4: This move is more unusual, but compared with The King's pawn opening, it is better, and compared to the King's Pawn Game, it is about the same, except with a higher draw rate.
moves.4. Nxd4: I was debating on whether I should do Scotch Gambit, or Scotch game, but I decided to Go with Scotch Game, as it has a higher win rate.
moves.5. Qxd4: And Queen captures back, while indirectly pinning down the darksworn bishop. ( Bishop Moves away, Qxg7 ) Usually, you should develop your Queen last, though.
moves.5... d6: Very Common response, but Nf6 is better.
moves.7. Bg5: I dunno why I chose that move. I guess I just favor pinning down knights.
moves.8... O-O: Of course. He castles. My opponent has a pretty bad position right now.
moves.9. O-O-O: I like Queenside better than Kingside.
moves.10. Bxe7: Moving back would have been kinda useless...
moves.11... Qe5: Of course. You try to exchange instead of giving up your Queen. He just blundered away your bishop, by the way. A better move would have been Qd8. Note that my opponent made this move very hastily.
moves.12. Qxe5: Still think he did a dumb move, though.
moves.12... dxe5 13. Ne7+: They Take back, Then I play Ne7+! He will have a horrible game now.
moves.13... Kh8 14. Rd8: Now he'll definitely lose his bishop. He offered a draw, but I declined.
moves.14... g6: Just to let the king have some space, because there is nothing else he can do for the bishop.
moves.15... Kg7: He probably didn't want to be smothered into one corner, and/or he might of been afraid of the possible attack with Bf7.
moves.16. Rhd1: Bringing out my other rook and gaining 2 rooks on one file/ doubling up my rooks.
moves.16... Nf6: Now he wants to exchange!? That was a pretty decent move, though.
moves.17. Rxf8 Kxf8 18. Rd8+: We both took, and I check now. It was either this, lose a pawn, or lose a knight.
moves.19... a5: Now he'll start moving the h and a pawn up.
moves.20. g4: Stopping H pawn from trying to advance.
moves.20... a4: I really think there was a better move here, but, oh well.
moves.21. g5 Nh5: Threaten knight, knight moves away, becomes isolated. Ng8 wouldn't have been any better.
moves.22... c6: Seriously, I was kinda expecting Nf4.
moves.23. b4: Trying to avoid backing up my bishop.
moves.27. Bd7 Ne6 28. Bxe6 fxe6: Simple exchange, though some rank bishop higher than knight.
moves.29. Rd7+ Kf8 30. Nd6: Finally freed the rook and the Knight.
moves.31. Rxh7: Extra pieces, and Black also has to worry about the possible rook skewer.
moves.35... Rf2+ 36. Kc3: Pawns are the key point in the middle-end and the end game.
moves.37. Rh6+ Kg7 38. Ne8+ Kf7: They'll get a pawn back, now.
moves.41... Rc4+ 42. Kb3: Now I start Threatening his A pawn.
moves.43. bxc5 Rxc5 44. Kxa3 Rxc2: Only a pawn and a knight up after that. I thought it would be more, but at least Black will have a harder time winning.
moves.45. Nh5: I could have done Kb4, but I decided to try to advance my pawns further.
moves.45... Rg2 46. Rg7 Kf5: Attacking pawn on G file now.
moves.47... e4: Trying to advance his pawn in hopes he can get there before my promoted pawn gets to it.
moves.51... Kxg5 52. Rxe2 Rxe2 53. Qxe2: Got the pawn, and the endgame officially starts.
moves.53... Kf5 54. Qxb5+: All pawns down, the best he can do is stalemate now.
moves.54... Kg6 55. Kb4 Kf7 56. a4 Ke7 57. a5: Absolutely hopeless of even a stalemate, now.
moves.60. a8=Q: You know, my opponent offered a draw here. Well, promoting again. The a and h file pawns are probably the easiest to promote.
moves.61. Qac6+ Ke7 62. Qe5+ Kf7 63. Qg7#: And with that, the game is won. Good thing, too, because I was 2 minutes away from timing out. I wonder if there was a quicker checkmate... Well, if you find one, tell me!
